repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Emergency Fire Prevention and
            Control Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts. Some lessons of
            experience suggest the following. The Bank is better
            positioned if involved from the outset in an emergency
            response situation, for it allows rapid financing, in this
            case, from the National Environment Project, and transfer
            funds for emergency and preparatory work. Thus, fire
            prevention activities actually started even before the loan
            agreement was signed. It is reinforced that for emergency
            operations, project design needs to be flexible, in light of
            changing circumstances, and, supervision should be intensive
            due to the fast preparation, and implementation. Notably, in
            an emergency, inaction may be politically or psychologically
            unacceptable. Once large-scale fires occur, the costs of
            stopping them are prohibitive. In many cases, it may be
            impossible to contain fires in remote areas, and even then,
            the government must act, not only to avoid the spread of
            fire to other sensitive areas such as protected areas and
            indigenous lands, but to give the general public a sense of
            safety and security. Emergency projects must be followed by
            a long-term strategy to prevent future emergencies, and,
            decentralization and partnerships are essential on the field.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Amazon Emergency Fire Prevention
            and Control Project (PROARCO)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Amazon Emergency Fire Prevention and
            Control Project (PROARCO) aims to prevent and control
            large-scale wildfires in the southern part of the Brazilian
            Amazon during the dry season of 1998 and to generate lessons
            regarding forest fire prevention and suppression techniques.
            There are four components including project coordination,
            monitoring and evaluation, and studies. The other three
            components comprise 1) risk assessment and fire monitoring,
            which uses appropriate technology and methods for assessing
            fire risk through integrating soil moisture maps, forest
            type maps, and human activity maps; and initiates studies
            and long-range planning to identify and respond to such
            issues as the potential for increased flammability of burned
            areas; 2) forest fire prevention, which develops technical
            assistance and educational campaigns for local communities
            and different stakeholders in high risk areas to provide
            guidance on the risks and consequences of uncontrolled
            burning; provides training and equipment to fire combat
            brigades; and conducts intensive enforcement operations and
            compliance to regulations to prevent and regulate illegal
            burning activities; and 3) forest fire suppression, which
            develops contingency plans to combat forest fires and refers
            control of major fires to a federal task force.
